title: Lesson 11: Cross Products and Linear Transformations
lesson_title: Cross products in the light of linear transformations
objectives: Understand the determinant formula for cross products

cards.front: How do you compute the 3D cross product using a determinant?
cards.back:
\( \vec{v} \times \vec{w} = \det \begin{pmatrix} \hat{i} & v_1 & w_1 \\ \hat{j} & v_2 & w_2 \\ \hat{k} & v_3 & w_3 \end{pmatrix} \)

Expand along the first column with basis vectors \( \hat{i}, \hat{j}, \hat{k} \).

cards.front: What is the formula for \( \vec{v} \times \vec{w} \) in terms of components?
cards.back:
\( \vec{v} \times \vec{w} = \hat{i}(v_2 w_3 - v_3 w_2) + \hat{j}(v_3 w_1 - v_1 w_3) + \hat{k}(v_1 w_2 - v_2 w_1) \)

Or as a vector:
\( \begin{bmatrix} v_2 w_3 - v_3 w_2 \\ v_3 w_1 - v_1 w_3 \\ v_1 w_2 - v_2 w_1 \end{bmatrix} \)

cards.front: How does duality explain the cross product?
cards.back:
Treating \( \det([\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}]) \) as a linear function of \( \vec{u} \) (with \( \vec{v}, \vec{w} \) fixed), there exists a dual vector \( \vec{p} \) such that:

\( \vec{p} \cdot \vec{u} = \det([\vec{u}, \vec{v}, \vec{w}]) \)

This dual vector \( \vec{p} \) is exactly \( \vec{v} \times \vec{w} \).

cards.front: Why does the determinant formula give a vector perpendicular to both inputs?
cards.back:
The dual vector (cross product) must give zero when dotted with \( \vec{v} \) or \( \vec{w} \) (since det is zero when two columns are identical).

Zero dot product means perpendicular.
